newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU asks Russia to reconsider vodka quotas.
newsitem.headline: EU asks Russia to reconsider vodka quotas.

text.p: European Union exports of vodka and ethyl alcohol to Russia will fall by nearly 75 percent if Moscow goes ahead with plans to impose import quotas from next year, the European Commission said on Wednesday.
The Commission said Russian plans to introduce an import limit of 100 million litres of vodka and 10 million litres of ethyl alcohol from January 1 would particularly hurt EU producers.
A Commission spokesman said Russia was limiting EU exports to 50 million litres next year from 200 million litres in 1995.
EU exports of alcohol and liquor to Russia in 1995 were worth 440 million European currency units, of which vodka made up 247.7 million Ecus, he said.
He said the quota went against the spirit of an EU-Russia trade agreement, and urged Moscow to reconsider.
Russian producers have complained that the cash-strapped national industry has suffered under a flow of cheap and low-quality foreign spirits, much of it imported tax-free from neighbouring states.

Many experts and government officials have been involved in debates about whether introducing import quotas could help domestic alcohol producers or would only harm them by artificially easing competition at home.
Opponents of the limitations say that the Russian alcohol market is far from saturated and that national producers could operate alongside importers.
